citeinfo.title: Water withdrawal and consumption estimates for thermoelectric power plants in the United States, 2015 (ver. 1.1, February 2021)
citeinfo.geoform: machine-readable, tabular data (i.e., CSV), and Excel spreadsheet data

citeinfo.title: Withdrawal and consumption of water by thermoelectric power plants in the United States, 2015

descript.abstract: This dataset presents water withdrawal estimates, consumption estimates, and associated information for 1,122 water-using, utility-scale thermoelectric power plants in the United States for 2015. The U.S. Geological Survey (USGS) developed models to estimate thermoelectric water use based on linked heat-and-water budgets, including thermodynamically plausible ranges of minimum and maximum withdrawal and consumption, to provide a consistent method for water-use estimation across the fleet of U.S. thermoelectric plants. Historically, thermoelectric water withdrawal and consumption has been estimated by the Department of Energy's Energy Information Administration (EIA) based on surveys of plant operator-reported data, and the USGS's 5-year water-use reports based on compiling data from State water agencies, plant operators, and the EIA. The USGS models provide independent estimates from plant operator-reported data. The total estimated withdrawal for 2015 was about 103 billion gallons per day (Bgal/d), and total estimated consumption was about 2.7 Bgal/d. This data release supports the findings published in Harris and Diehl (2019).
descript.purpose: The need for reliable estimates of the amount of water withdrawn and consumed by thermoelectric power plants is garnering increased attention due to the Nationâ€™s growing demand for water and energy. Water withdrawals for thermoelectric power generation are the largest category of water withdrawals in the United States (Dieter and others, 2018), and water consumption represents a small but substantial share of total U.S. water consumption especially at smaller spatial scales (i.e., watersheds, counties). Reported and estimated thermoelectric water withdrawals and consumption vary among Federal datasets. The USGS models provide independent estimates from plant operator-reported data and a consistent method for estimating water use across the fleet of U.S. thermoelectric plants.

attracc.attraccr: The attribute values have been cross-checked with reported and published data for USGS model estimates and EIA-reported data.

dataqual.logic: Data were compared to published EIA datasets. Data are complete and accurate with no duplications or omissions.
dataqual.complete: Dataset is considered complete for the information presented, as described in the abstract. Users are advised to read the rest of the metadata record carefully for additional details.

horizpa.horizpar: Power plant location data obtained from EIA, U.S. Environmental Protection Agency (EPA), and National Energy Technology Laboratory (NETL) databases were evaluated, verified, and where needed, modified using standard geographic information system (GIS) procedures (Diehl and others, 2013).

vertacc.vertaccr: Power plant location data obtained from EIA, U.S. Environmental Protection Agency (EPA), and National Energy Technology Laboratory (NETL) databases were evaluated, verified, and where needed, modified using standard geographic information system (GIS) procedures (Diehl and others, 2013).

citeinfo.origin: Diehl, T.H., Harris, M.A., Murphy, J.C., Hutson, S.S., and Ladd, D.E.
citeinfo.title: Methods for estimating water consumption for thermoelectric power plants in the United States

srcinfo.srccontr: data were integral to this work

procstep.procdesc: File "2015_TE_input_data": The establishment of the 2015 plant list, categorization of plants according to generation and cooling-system technologies, determination of environmental input variables, and condenser duty calculations followed the methodologies of Diehl and others (2013) and Diehl and Harris (2014). Any variations to the methodology are explained in this data release product's companion publication, Harris M.A., and Diehl, T.H., 2019, Withdrawal and consumption of water by thermoelectric power plants in the United States, 2015.

File "2015_TE_estimates": The USGS model team estimated thermoelectric water withdrawals and consumption for power plants in the U.S. with generating capacities of at least one megawatt for 2015 (Diehl and others, 2013Í¾ Diehl and Harris, 2014). Any variations to the methodology are explained in this data release product's companion publication, Harris M.A., and Diehl, T.H., 2019, Withdrawal and consumption of water by thermoelectric power plants in the United States, 2015.

attrdomv.udom: The majority of water system names are provided by the EIA. However, some names were not reported to EIA and are indicated by a value of â€œ-NR-â€œ.

attr.attrdef: USGS model-assigned cooling-system technology category

edom.edomvd: Power plants that have more than one cooling system type

A cooling system in which fresh water is withdrawn from a surface-water source other than a recirculating pond to condense the steam used to generate electricity and that discharges the water back to surface water at a higher temperature.

A cooling system in which saline water is withdrawn from a surface-water source other than a recirculating pond to condense the steam used to generate electricity and that discharges the water back to surface water at a higher temperature.
A cooling system in which water is circulated through condensers, cooled in a cooling pond, and then returned to the condenser.
A cooling system in which water is circulated through condensers, cooled in a wet cooling tower, and then returned to the condenser.

attr.attrdef: The generation technology/fuel used to generate electricity.

edom.edomvd: A thermoelectric combustion-steam power plant where more than 90 percent of the heat that generates its electricity comes from a biomass fuel source.
A thermoelectric combustion-steam power plant where more than 90 percent of the heat that generates its electricity comes from a coal fuel source.
A thermoelectric power plant that uses more than one fuel type and where less than 90 percent of the heat that generates its electricity comes from a single fuel source.
A thermoelectric combustion-steam power plant where more than 90 percent of the heat that generates its electricity comes from a gas fuel source.

Natural Gas Combined Cycle. A thermoelectric combined-cycle power plant where more than 90 percent of the heat that generates its electricity comes from a gas-fired combustion turbine and a steam turbine combined cycleÍ¾ most commonly powered by natural gas.
A thermoelectric nuclear power plant where more than 90 percent of the heat that generates its electricity comes from nuclear fission.
A thermoelectric combustion-steam power plant where more than 90 percent of the heat that generates its electricity comes from an oil fuel source.

Oil Combined Cycle. A thermoelectric combined-cycle power plant where more than 90 percent of the heat that generates its electricity comes from a combustion turbine and a steam turbine combined cycle powered by an oil fuel source.

attr.attrdef: USGS-assigned cooling water sourceÍ¾ most are directly from EIA, but some were added for plants that did not report a water source code if the name of the water source provided sufficient information to make a determination. Some plants have multiple cooling water sources and therefore may have more than one code for this attribute (e.g., GW & PD).

edom.edomvd: Surface Water (ex: river, canal, bay)
edom.edomvds: Department of Energy - Energy Information Administration (EIA)

edom.edomvd: Groundwater (ex: well, aquifer)
edom.edomvds: Department of Energy - Energy Information Administration (EIA)

edom.edomvd: Plant Discharge Water (ex: wastewater treatment discharge)
edom.edomvds: Department of Energy - Energy Information Administration (EIA)

edom.edomvd: Other
edom.edomvds: Department of Energy - Energy Information Administration (EIA)

edom.edomvd: Not reportedÍ¾ Plants were either not required to report water-use data to EIA, or were required, but did not report water-use data to EIA, and USGS could not determine the water source based on reported data.

attr.attrdef: USGS-assigned cooling water type codesÍ¾ most are directly from EIA, but some were added for plants that did not report a water type code if the name of the water source provided sufficient information to make a determination. Some plants have multiple cooling water types and therefore may have more than one code for this attribute (e.g., FR & BE).

edom.edomvd: Reclaimed wastewater
edom.edomvds: Department of Energy - Energy Information Administration (EIA)

edom.edomvd: Brackish water
edom.edomvds: Department of Energy - Energy Information Administration (EIA)

edom.edomvd: Freshwater; water that contains less than 1,000 milligrams per liter (mg/L) of dissolved solids.
Saline waterÍ¾ water that contains 1,000 milligrams per liter (mg/L) or more of dissolved solids.
Other
edom.edomvds: Department of Energy - Energy Information Administration (EIA)

edom.edomvd: Not reportedÍ¾ Plants were either not required to report water-use data to EIA, or were required, but did not report water-use data to EIA, and USGS could not determine the water type based on reported data.

attr.attrdef: USGS best estimate of annual water withdrawal in million gallons per day (Mgal/d).
USGS best estimate of annual water consumption in million gallons per day (Mgal/d).
USGS model-estimated thermodynamically plausible minimum annual withdrawal in million gallons per day (Mgal/d)
USGS model-estimated thermodynamically plausible maximum annual withdrawal in million gallons per day (Mgal/d)
USGS model-estimated thermodynamically plausible minimum annual consumption in million gallons per day (Mgal/d)
USGS model-estimated thermodynamically plausible maximum annual consumption in million gallons per day (Mgal/d)
Total EIA-reported net generation for water-using generators at each plant in megawatt-hours (MWh)

attr.attrdef: USGS model-assigned cooling-system technology category

edom.edomvd: Power plants that have more than one cooling system type

A cooling system in which fresh water is withdrawn from a surface-water source other than a recirculating pond to condense the steam used to generate electricity and that discharges the water back to surface water at a higher temperature.

A cooling system in which saline water is withdrawn from a surface-water source other than a recirculating pond to condense the steam used to generate electricity and that discharges the water back to surface water at a higher temperature.
A cooling system in which water is circulated through condensers, cooled in a cooling pond, and then returned to the condenser.
A cooling system in which water is circulated through condensers, cooled in a wet cooling tower, and then returned to the condenser.

attr.attrdef: USGS modeling approach for estimating withdrawal and consumption as described in Diehl and others (2013), and Diehl and Harris (2014).

edom.edomvd: A cooling system in which fresh water is withdrawn from a LAKE to condense the steam used to generate electricity and that discharges the water back to a LAKE at a higher temperature. Lakes were distinguished from ponds as having irregular, natural shorelines, and enough inflow to compensate for evaporation. Please note that for some plants with this model type designation the water source may indicate a river (e.g., Tennessee River). For all cases, these plants are located on reservoirs that have been constructed along the stream reach of these large rivers.

A cooling system in which fresh water is withdrawn from a POND to condense the steam used to generate electricity and that discharges the water back to a POND at a higher temperature. Once-through ponds were distinguished from recirculating ponds as having enough inflow to compensate for evaporation. Ponds were also distinguished from lakes as lacking irregular, natural shorelines.
A cooling system in which fresh water is withdrawn from a RIVER to condense the steam used to generate electricity and that discharges the water back to a RIVER at a higher temperature.

A cooling system in which saline water is withdrawn from a coastal, surface-water source to condense the steam used to generate electricity and that discharges the water back to a coastal, surface water source at a higher temperature.

A cooling system in which water is circulated through condensers, cooled in a cooling pond, and then returned to the condenser. Recirculating cooling ponds are separate from the natural hydrology surrounding the power plant (e.g., levees), and have no inflow or outflow besides direct precipitation and evaporation.
A cooling system in which water is circulated through condensers, cooled in a wet cooling tower, and then returned to the condenser.

attr.attrdef: The percentage of condenser duty (CD) (the amount of waste heat delivered to the cooling system through the condenser) that is allocated to the cooling system. Most boiler-generator-cooling system associations at thermoelectric power plants result in 100 percent CD allocation to cooling systems. However, there are 46 COMPLEX "COOLING_TYPE" plants that have more than one type of cooling system located on a single boiler-generator-cooling system association group. For those plants, the CD was allocated between the two cooling models using professional judgement (for example, at plant ID 46, 80 percent of the CD was allocated to the once-through lake cooling model and 20 percent to the recirculating tower model). Additionally, for plants with single boiler-generator-cooling system association groups, 100 percent of the CD was allocated to each of the cooling system types (for example, at plant ID 46, 100 percent of the CD was allocated to the once-through lake cooling model and 100 percent to the recirculating tower model). This results in the minimum and maximum withdrawal and consumption estimates at single boiler-generator-cooling system association groups, where the maximum withdrawal and minimum consumption is associated with the once-through system, and the minimum withdrawal and maximum consumption is associated with the recirculating cooling system.
Elevation of power plant in feet (ft), from sea level, vertical datum WGS84.

The water-surface area of a recirculating cooling pond in acres. For most once-through systems, the "1,000,000" acres represents the nominal surface-water area of the plume created by the return flow of heated water that has passed through the condenser (Diehl and others, 2013).

The calculated condenser duty (CD) (Diehl and others, 2013) for the boiler-generator-cooling system unit-association group for January, 2015. The condenser duty is the amount of waste heat delivered to the cooling system through the condenser.

The calculated condenser duty (CD) (Diehl and others, 2013) for the boiler-generator-cooling system unit-association group for February, 2015. The condenser duty is the amount of waste heat delivered to the cooling system through the condenser.

The calculated condenser duty (CD) (Diehl and others, 2013) for the boiler-generator-cooling system unit-association group for March, 2015. The condenser duty is the amount of waste heat delivered to the cooling system through the condenser.

The calculated condenser duty (CD) (Diehl and others, 2013) for the boiler-generator-cooling system unit-association group for April, 2015. The condenser duty is the amount of waste heat delivered to the cooling system through the condenser.

The calculated condenser duty (CD) (Diehl and others, 2013) for the boiler-generator-cooling system unit-association group for May, 2015. The condenser duty is the amount of waste heat delivered to the cooling system through the condenser.

The calculated condenser duty (CD) (Diehl and others, 2013) for the boiler-generator-cooling system unit-association group for June, 2015. The condenser duty is the amount of waste heat delivered to the cooling system through the condenser.

The calculated condenser duty (CD) (Diehl and others, 2013) for the boiler-generator-cooling system unit-association group for July, 2015. The condenser duty is the amount of waste heat delivered to the cooling system through the condenser.

The calculated condenser duty (CD) (Diehl and others, 2013) for the boiler-generator-cooling system unit-association group for August, 2015. The condenser duty is the amount of waste heat delivered to the cooling system through the condenser.

The calculated condenser duty (CD) (Diehl and others, 2013) for the boiler-generator-cooling system unit-association group for September, 2015. The condenser duty is the amount of waste heat delivered to the cooling system through the condenser.

The calculated condenser duty (CD) (Diehl and others, 2013) for the boiler-generator-cooling system unit-association group for October, 2015. The condenser duty is the amount of waste heat delivered to the cooling system through the condenser.

The calculated condenser duty (CD) (Diehl and others, 2013) for the boiler-generator-cooling system unit-association group for November, 2015. The condenser duty is the amount of waste heat delivered to the cooling system through the condenser.

The calculated condenser duty (CD) (Diehl and others, 2013) for the boiler-generator-cooling system unit-association group for December, 2015. The condenser duty is the amount of waste heat delivered to the cooling system through the condenser.

cntaddr.address: Mail Stop 302, W 6th Ave Kipling St

distinfo.distliab: Unless otherwise stated, all data, metadata and related materials are considered to satisfy the quality standards relative to the purpose for which the data were collected. Although these data and associated metadata have been reviewed for accuracy and completeness and approved for release by the U.S. Geological Survey (USGS), no warranty expressed or implied is made regarding the display or utility of the data on any other system or for general or scientific purposes, nor shall the act of distribution constitute any such warranty. Any use of trade, firm, or product names is for descriptive purposes only and does not imply endorsement by the U.S. Government.
distinfo.techpreq: The user must have Microsoft Office 2010. In addition to the Microsoft Excel files (.xlsx and .xls), the data will also be available as a comma-separated values (.csv) file.
